Jesca Hoop returns with her third album The House That Jack Built on her own label on June 25th 2012.

The House That Jack Built deftly showcases its authorÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s unflinching tendency to pull focus from widescreen to close-up. Part siren song, part grim warning, it achieves a perspective-warping balance between the haunting intimacy of HoopÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s delivery and an unconfined air of horizon-scanning grandeur from the outset Ã¢â‚¬â€œ tempestuous, moodily melodic opener Ã¢â‚¬ËœBorn ToÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ shares this striking duality with later highlights Ã¢â‚¬ËœWhen IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m AsleepÃ¢â‚¬â„¢, Ã¢â‚¬ËœPeacemakerÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ and Ã¢â‚¬ËœDeeper DevastationÃ¢â‚¬â„¢.

It arrives with more than a few splashes on its hands. Life and death; light and dark; sex and war; head and heart: The House That Jack Built offers up as much in celebration of the macabre as it does in mistrust of the familiar, with a twist of humour. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s steeped in an allusion to biology, nature and humanity, but drops precious few clues as to whether its next rush of imagery is set to beguile or repel.
